item.title: When marginal and conditional logistic model estimates diverge
item.author: keith.goldfeld@nyumc.org (Keith Goldfeld)
item.description: Say we have an intervention that is assigned at a group or cluster level but the outcome is measured at an individual level (e.g. students in different schools, eyes on different individuals). And, say this outcome is binary; that is, something happens, or it doesn’t. (This is important, because none of this is true if the outcome is continuous and at close to normally distributed.) If we want to measure the effect of the intervention - perhaps the risk difference, risk ratio, or odds ratio - it can really matter if we are interested in the marginal effect or the conditional effect, because there is a good chance they won’t be the same.
